description: Unknown; attested from early 19th century, in the sense "to slip, slide".

entries.meaning: (cooking) A thick sauce or spread that is to be slathered (spread thickly) onto food.

examples: [The river] VÃ¡n in SnE I 21 is mentioned as coming from the slather of the bound Fenris Wolf.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) A generous or abundant quantity.
examples: In her eyes the manse people were quite fabulously rich, and no doubt those girls had slathers of shoes and stockings.

verbs.description: slather (third-person singular simple present slathers, present participle slathering, simple past and past participle slathered) (transitive)

entries.meaning: To spread something thickly on something else; to coat well.
examples: I slathered jam on my toast.

entries.meaning: (often followed by with) To apply generously upon.
examples: I slathered my toast with jam.
